M.G.L. c. 119, \u00a7 51A.proposition: a referral to the Department of Children and Families (DCF) for investigation pursuant to M.G.L. c. 119, § 51A, if the Court determines a report is appropriate;

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208 (provisions governing divorce, separation, and custody orders) (see provisions regarding orders for custody and modifications);

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C (Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement Act — jurisdictional matters for child custody and visitation);

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 119, \u00a7 51A.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 119, § 51A (duty to report suspected child abuse or neglect and DCF investigation authority);

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 119, \u00a7\u00a7 39.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 119, §§ 39 et seq. (general child welfare provisions);

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231, \u00a7 60B.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231, § 60B (expungement and sealing of certain records — relevant to records inquiries where appropriate).

In re Custody of a Minor, 378 Mass. 1004.raw_text: In re Custody of a Minor, 378 Mass. 1004 (1979)
In re Custody of a Minor, 378 Mass. 1004.proposition: In re Custody of a Minor, 378 Mass. 1004 (1979) (discussing custody determinations and best interests of the child);

Custody of a Minor, 380 Mass. 556 (1980).proposition: Custody of a Minor, 380 Mass. 556 (1980) (material change in circumstances standard);
Custody of a Minor, 380 Mass. 556 (1980).support_reasoning: The opinion deals with juvenile transfer proceedings and defects in the transfer process, not with modification of child custody orders or a ‘material change in circumstances’ standard. Nowhere does the court articulate or apply a material-change test; instead it addresses supervisory powers under G.L. c. 211, § 3, and the adequacy of juvenile court findings under G.L. c. 119, § 61. Using this case as authority for a material change in circumstances standard is therefore inaccurate.
Custody of a Minor, 380 Mass. 556 (1980).relevant_excerpt: Serious deficiency in the subsidiary findings should count as a faulty step in the process of transfer, examinable as above indicated. A resume of the present procedure for transfer shows those findings to be of vital significance. By G. L. c. 119, § 61, where a delinquency complaint alleges that a child between the ages of fourteen and seventeen has committed “an offense involving the infliction or threat of serious bodily harm,” the Juvenile Court, after a hearing and finding of probable cause, shall go on to consider evidence of five factors...

Custody of a Minor, 436 Mass. 484 (2002).proposition: Custody of a Minor, 436 Mass. 484 (2002) (factors in determining best interests);
Custody of a Minor, 436 Mass. 484 (2002).case_name: Mayor of Cambridge v. Secretary of the Commonwealth
Custody of a Minor, 436 Mass. 484 (2002).support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is not Custody of a Minor, 436 Mass. 484 (2002); it is a redistricting/mandamus case concerning the constitutionality of a legislative redistricting statute and standards under art. 101. It does not discuss child custody, best interests of the child, or any factors used in a best-interests analysis. Therefore, this text does not support the proposition that Custody of a Minor, 436 Mass. 484 (2002), sets out factors for determining best interests.
Custody of a Minor, 436 Mass. 484 (2002).relevant_excerpt: We have traditionally accorded the Legislature substantial deference in determining how to strike the proper balance among the various directives and goals laid out by State and Federal law. Brookline v. Secretary of the Commonwealth, supra at 418, quoting Growe v. Emison, 507 U.S. 25, 34 (1993). ("Reapportionment ... is primarily the duty and responsibility of the State through its legislative or other body . . ."). The issue we must resolve is not whether a better plan exists, but "whether, once these various mandates and considerations are taken into account, the Legislature has unduly departed from the directive in art. 101 on which the plaintiffs rely."

Casey v. Casey, 363 Mass. 792 (1973).proposition: Casey v. Casey, 363 Mass. 792 (1973) (courts assess best interests);
Casey v. Casey, 363 Mass. 792 (1973).support_reasoning: This is a criminal homicide appeal dealing with evidentiary issues, effectiveness of counsel, and prosecutorial argument, not a family-law or custody matter. The court does not discuss or apply any “best interests” standard (such as the best interests of a child) or any comparable doctrinal test. Citing Casey v. Casey (1973) for the general proposition that courts assess best interests is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by the opinion.
Casey v. Casey, 363 Mass. 792 (1973).relevant_excerpt:
On our review of the whole case, we find no occasion to order a new trial or to grant any other relief to the defendant. G. L. c. 278, § 33E.

Judgment affirmed.

Foss v. Foss, 400 Mass. 684 (1987).proposition: Foss v. Foss, 400 Mass. 684 (1987) (modification when circumstances materially change);
Foss v. Foss, 400 Mass. 684 (1987).support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is a criminal case about aggravated rape, indecent assault and battery, kidnapping, jury instructions, prosecutorial argument, duplicative convictions, and delay in preparation of trial transcripts. It does not discuss domestic relations, divorce, or modification of judgments based on a material change in circumstances. Therefore, it does not support the cited proposition regarding modification when circumstances materially change.
Foss v. Foss, 400 Mass. 684 (1987).relevant_excerpt: 6. Finally, the defendants argue that the judge erred in denying their postconviction motion to dismiss the indictments because of delay in the preparation of the trial transcripts. ... In view of our conclusion that the defendants are not entitled to a new trial, the defendants have not demonstrated that they were prejudiced by the delay.

S.C. v. M.A., 431 Mass. 605 (2000).proposition: S.C. v. M.A., 431 Mass. 605 (2000) (safety of the child as paramount);
S.C. v. M.A., 431 Mass. 605 (2000).support_reasoning: This opinion is a civil procedure/jurisdiction case about District Court and Superior Court authority and the effect of St. 1996, c. 358 on summary process actions. It does not involve child custody, child welfare, or any discussion of the safety of a child as a paramount consideration. Citing this case for the proposition that it establishes the safety of the child as paramount is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by its holding or reasoning.
S.C. v. M.A., 431 Mass. 605 (2000).relevant_excerpt: In interpreting statutes we use the plain language of the statute where the language is unambiguous. ... The plain language of St. 1996, c. 358, is clear. In summary, § 4 grants exclusive original jurisdiction to the District Courts in Norfolk and Middlesex counties, for all civil actions otherwise subject to G. L. c. 231, §§ 97-107, if there is a reasonable likelihood that the plaintiff’s recovery will not exceed $25,000; it grants exclusive original jurisdiction to the Superior Court for all civil actions otherwise subject to G. L. c. 231, §§ 97-107, if there is a reasonable likelihood that the plaintiff’s recovery will exceed $25,000.

S.M. v. S.P., 78 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (201.raw_text: S.M. v. S.P., 78 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2010)
S.M. v. S.P., 78 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (201.proposition: S.M. v. S.P., 78 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2010) (supervised visitation where necessary to protect a child);
S.M. v. S.P., 78 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (201.case_name: 81 Spooner Road, LLC v. Zoning Board of Appeals
S.M. v. S.P., 78 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (201.support_reasoning: This opinion is a zoning/land-use case about floor area ratio, building permits, standing, and infectious invalidity. It does not involve family law, custody, or visitation, nor does it discuss supervised visitation or child protection. The proposition about supervised visitation is therefore unrelated and not supported by this case.
S.M. v. S.P., 78 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (201.relevant_excerpt: A zoning enforcement appeal procedure has been held to be necessary to protect a person aggrieved by a violation of the zoning law, under circumstances where he or she has not had notice of, and a fair opportunity to challenge, the permit within the thirty-day appeal period... Without a right of appeal under c. 40A, an aggrieved party who lacks notice of a local zoning decision would be left without a remedy to prevent further overcrowding or dense building lot coverage, in his or her immediate neighborhood.

Walsh v. Walsh, 425 Mass. 47 (1997).proposition: Walsh v. Walsh, 425 Mass. 47 (1997) (custody modification principles and weighing of parental rights vs. child welfare);

Meservey v. Swanson, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Meservey v. Swanson, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 785 (1989)
Meservey v. Swanson, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: Meservey v. Swanson, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 785 (1989) (court may condition parenting time on safeguards where necessary for child safety);
Meservey v. Swanson, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about the scope of Massachusetts’ pimping statute, G.L. c. 272, § 7, and whether the defendant’s conduct constituted ‘deriving support’ from prostitution. It does not involve family law, custody, parenting time, or any discussion of conditioning visitation on safeguards for child safety. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition about conditioning parenting time.
Meservey v. Swanson, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt:
General Laws c. 272, § 7, set forth in the appendix, is meant to deal with the “pimp or purveyor,” and makes the crime a felony. It sets a much more severe penalty than does either G. L. c. 272, § 53, or G. L. c. 272, § 53A, also set forth in the appendix, under which prostitution, a misdemeanor, may be punished.

…

In the context of its purpose, to punish the “pimp or purveyor,” whose activities were considered by the Legislature more egregious than prostitution, we think that the furnishing of transportation and waiting in exchange for occasional gas money and drugs by a friend (male or female) does not come within the prohibition…

In re Marriage of Pantaleoni, 70 Mass. A.raw_text: In re Marriage of Pantaleoni, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 730 (2007)
In re Marriage of Pantaleoni, 70 Mass. A.proposition: In re Marriage of Pantaleoni, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 730 (2007) (evidentiary burdens in modification and the importance of evaluating home environment and third parties present).
In re Marriage of Pantaleoni, 70 Mass. A.support_reasoning: This opinion is a juvenile delinquency/Miranda case, not a domestic relations or modification proceeding, and it does not discuss evidentiary burdens in modification actions or evaluation of a child’s home environment and third parties in that context. The holding concerns whether a foster parent may act as an “interested adult” during a juvenile’s custodial interrogation. The proposition attributed to the case misidentifies both the subject matter and the legal principle for which it provides authority.
In re Marriage of Pantaleoni, 70 Mass. A.relevant_excerpt: “Here, there is no dispute that the defendant’s foster mother was present, understood the nature of the Miranda rights, and had an opportunity to discuss those rights with the defendant. Accordingly, the sole issue before us is a global one: whether foster parents generally, by nature of their contractual relationship with the State, can ever serve as interested adults.”
